newsitem.title: UK: Retailers setback by unexpectedly weak sales data.
newsitem.headline: Retailers setback by unexpectedly weak sales data.

text.p: Retailing stocks were mostly lower on Wednesday after surprising weak retail sales in July dimmed hopes that the sector was enjoying a return of consumer confidence.
Marks & Spencer fell 7p to 492p, Next was down 7p to 557p and Kingfisher had lost 8p to 658.5p by 1005 GMT.
UK retail sales fell 0.6 percent in July against expectations of a 0.2 percent rise.
"This is certainly a lot weaker than the market expected," said David Coleman, economist at CIBC Wood Gundy.
On Tuesday, most shares in the sector had risen on the back of strong interim profit figures from discount retailer Argos, and in anticipation of strengthening retail sales.

"Market makers are using these figures as an excuse for profit-taking, after a couple of days of good performances in the sector," said Nick Bubb, retail analyst at Mees Pierson who maintains his bullish outlook for retailers.
"The retail consortium had already told us that sales in July would be less buoyant than June, but I expect the figures to pick up again in August," he said.
Economists said the weak sales figures will now raise hopes the Chancellor could cut UK interest rates again.
"What could have been the final nail in the coffin of UK base rate cut hopes instead may have opened the lid," said Jeremy Hawkins, economist at Bank of America.
